title: U.S. Forces Attacked in Syria, State Media Says
summary: The Pentagon said two soldiers and a civilian interpreter were killed while supporting counterterror operations. They are the first U.S. casualties in Syria since the fall of the dictator Bashar al-Assad

title: Israel Says It Killed Senior Hamas Commander, Despite Cease-Fire
summary: Hamas said the attack on Saturday was a breach of the truce. The militant group did not comment on Israel’s claim to have killed one of its members.

title: Can Trump’s Grand Plans for Gaza Get Off the Drawing Board?
summary: The next steps for the president’s 20-point Gaza peace plan have been mired in uncertainty and a lack of detail, but that may be set to change. Here’s what to know.

title: MAHA Moms Are Angry at the E.P.A. Lee Zeldin Is Trying to Win Them Back.
summary: A split is emerging within Trump’s base as health activists accuse Mr. Zeldin of leading the agency to prioritize chemical industry interests over public health.

title: Trump’s ‘Pardon’ of Tina Peters Rejected by Colorado Officials
summary: The president’s stated intention to pardon Tina Peters, jailed for tampering with election machines in 2020, has set off a legal fight over the extent of Mr. Trump’s pardon powers.

title: The Young Conservatives Fixated on H-1B Visas
summary: For some Gen Z conservatives, H-1B visas are a hot new topic.

title: Venezuela Oil Tanker Seized by U.S. Was Part of Effort to Finance Cuba
summary: Firms with ties to Cuba are getting a larger share of Venezuelan oil exports, as the island’s security agents boost President Nicolás Maduro’s defenses.

title: Biden Has Raised Little of What He Needs to Build a Presidential Library
summary: His library foundation has told the I.R.S. that by the end of 2027 it expects to bring in just $11.3 million — not nearly enough for a traditional presidential library.

title: Russia Bombs Ukraine Port of Odesa Amid Peace Talks
summary: Much of Ukraine’s largest Black Sea port was without power, heat and water on Saturday after strikes from Russia, which has shown little appetite for a deal to end the war.

title: Ivan Urgant Was Russia’s Late-Night King Until Putin’s War in Ukraine
summary: Ivan Urgant was an unstoppable Russian megastar. Then he expressed opposition to President Vladimir V. Putin’s invasion of Ukraine.

title: Clean, Limitless Energy Exists. China Is Going Big in the Race to Harness It.
summary: Beijing is pouring vast resources into fusion research, while the U.S. wants private industry to lead the way. The winner could reshape civilization.

title: We Should Teach Our Students How to Think, Not What to Believe
summary: Gaza has turned California classrooms into political battlegrounds.

title: Baby Steps
summary: The antidote to our increasingly disembodied lives may lie in letting go of our inhibitions and dancing like kids do.

title: Woody Allen Is Not Sorry About His Friendship With Jeffrey Epstein
summary: The nonagenarian director is taking a slightly different tack than many of the other powerful people associated with the disgraced former financier.

title: Eric Adams Swaggered Into City Hall, and Now He’s Swaggering Out
summary: Interviewed as he prepares to leave office, Mayor Eric Adams said that he hadn’t gotten the credit he deserved and that certain forces had always been arrayed against him.

title: Jo Ann Allen Boyce Dies at 84; Braved Mobs in Integrating a School
summary: She was one of the Clinton 12, Black students who broke a race barrier by entering a Tennessee high school in 1956 in the face of harassment by white segregationists.

title: A Measles Outbreak Brings With It Echoes of the Pandemic
summary: In South Carolina, parents struggle to deal with infections that have brought quarantines and remote learning. Health care workers are bracing for an increase in cases.
